citeinfo.title: Wildlife population and harvest data for Forest Service 2010 RPA assessment

descript.abstract: The data documents trends in the populations and harvests of wildlife species across the United States, from 1955 to 2010, as one set of resource condition indicators as required by the Forest and Rangeland Renewable Resources Planning Act (RPA) of 1974. Data from a variety of sources were used to document recent historical trends in big game, small game, migratory game birds, furbearers, nongame, and imperiled species. Additionally, data reflect statistical models that related forest bird richness to human alteration of landscapes to forecast the likely response of forest birds to projected changes in land use and housing development over the next 50 years as reflected in three alternative future scenarios.
descript.purpose: In fulfillment of the Forest and Rangeland Renewable Resources Planning Act of 1974, the USDA Forest Service periodically assesses the condition and trends of the Nation's renewable resources. These data are in support of the Wildlife portion of the Assessment.
descript.supplinf:
This data publication contains the figures and data associated with Flather et al. (2013). Original metadata date was 05/08/2014. Minor metadata updates on 05/29/2014.
Minor metadata updates on 12/12/2016 and 02/27/2023.

spdom.descgeog: All counties within the United States (which includes Alaska and Hawaii). These counties are as defined by the following Arc shapefiles: st2m_alb.shp, ak_cty_2001.shp, and hi_cty_2001.shp. These shapefiles were subset from the 2001 shapefile downloaded from https://nationalmap.gov/.

classsys.classmod:
The taxonomy for a couple of species was not available, and the following taxomony was provided instead:
1. Geomyces destructans (referenced in Flather et al. 2013) was changed to Pseudogymnoascus destructans as per
Minnis, Andrew M.; Lindner, Daniel L. 2013. Phylogenetic evaluation of Geomyces and allies reveals no close relatives of Pseudogymnoascus destructans, comb. nov., in bat hibernacula of eastern North America. Fungal Biology 117(9):638-649. https://doi.org/10.1016/j.funbio.2013.07.001
This species was not in ITIS.gov, so the taxonomy was obtained from the Index Fungorum database (Index Fungorum database (https://www.indexfungorum.org/) on 5/6/2014.
2. Perimyotis subflavus is per: https://dnr.wi.gov/files/PDF/pubs/er/ER0706.pdf on 5/6/2014. The taxonomy was not in ITIS.gov, so it was obtained from the Animal Diversity Web on 5/6/2014: https://animaldiversity.org/accounts/Perimyotis_subflavus/classification/.
3. Dendragapus fuliginosus is per:
Banks, R.C.; Cicero C.; Dunn, J.L.; Kratter, A.W.; Rasmussen, P.C.; Remsen, J.V., Rising, J.D., Stotz, D.F. 2006. American Ornithologists' Union. The Auk 123(3): 926-936.
This species was not in ITIS.gov, so the taxonomy was obtained from the American Ornithologists' Union checklist on 5/6/2014:
Forty-seventh supplement to the American Ornithologists' Union check-list of North American birds. 2006. The Auk 123:926-936. https://americanornithology.org/
**** SPECIAL NOTE **** In Flather et al. (2013) (the publication associated with this data package) there were 2 species spelled incorrectly. In this metadata document we used the correct spelling.
Publication misspelling: Chen canagica Correct spelling used here: Chen canagia
Publication misspelling: Myotis sodalist Correct spelling used here: Myotis sodalis

idinfo.useconst:
These data were collected using funding from the U.S. Government and can be used without additional permissions or fees. If you use these data in a publication, presentation, or other research product please use the citation below when citing the data product:
Flather, Curtis H.; Knowles, Michael S.; Jones, Martin F.; Schilli, Carol J. 2014. Wildlife population and harvest data for Forest Service 2010 RPA Assessment. Fort Collins, CO: Forest Service Research Data Archive. https://doi.org/10.2737/RDS-2014-0009

cntperp.cntorg: USDA Forest Service, Rocky Mountain Research Station

idinfo.datacred: Funding for this project provided by USDA Forest Service, Washington Office; USDA Forest Service, Resources Planning Act (RPA) Assessment; and the USDA Forest Service, Rocky Mountain Research Station (RMRS), Human Dimensions Program. Data from this project were obtained from multiple sources. See the Source Citation section of this metadata document and Table 1 from Flather, Knowles, Jones, and Schilli (2013). Archival work, which involved preparing data and writing metadata, completed by Michael Knowles, RMRS.

citeinfo.title: Wildlife population and harvest trends in the United States: A technical document supporting the Forest Service 2010 RPA Assessment

pubinfo.publish: U.S. Department of Agriculture, Forest Service, Rocky Mountain Research Station

citeinfo.title: Housing growth in and near United States protected areas limits their conservation value

serinfo.sername: Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences

attracc.attraccr:
The data compiled are derived from a number of sources - each with its own strengths and limitations. Some sources support stronger inferences about the direction and magnitude of distributional or abundance changes than others. Sources are listed under Source Information.
There are differences in the way that various states estimate population and harvest. Because of these interstate differences, interpretations were focused on the trends in population and harvest rather than on the actual magnitude of the estimate for any particular time period. This strategy assumes that a consistent set of states can provide estimates for each 5-year reporting period and that within-state procedures have remained comparable over the 1975-2008 period. A number of factors may cause state agency data to violate these assumptions. Two of these factors data reporting gaps and changes to a State's procedures for estimating population or harvests - are addressed and methods used to minimize their impacts are described.
Changes to state agency procedures used to estimate harvests and/or populations were more problematic. State agency contacts were relied on to identify procedural changes that would affect comparability over time in the "comments" field in the electronic data entry form. In those identified cases, state-specific trends were examined to assess the effects of the procedural change on the interpretability of the trend over the 1975-2008 period. Discontinuities in trends were flagged, and contacting state agency biologists to determine if the harvest or population estimate could be made comparable over the time period was attempted. If the data could not be made comparable, then that particular state's data for that species were not included in the trend analysis. Note that the interpolation process previously described for data gaps was performed only on true data gaps and was not used in cases where a data gap was caused by the exclusion of data because of a lack of comparability within a state. In other words, when data were excluded because of procedural changes in estimating harvest or population, those gaps were not filled by interpolation based on the data before and after the gap; rather, they simply could not be included in the analysis of trends.
Because of the diversity of resident and common migrant species that occur within the United States, the status and trends of wildlife are addressed by major species categories including: (1) those commonly harvested for recreation, subsistence, or commercial gain (i.e., big game, small game, migratory game birds, and furbearers); (2) those not typically harvested but having high public interest (i.e., breeding birds, amphibians, bats, and pollinators); and (3) those that have been determined by formal population assessment to have extinction risks that warrant elevated conservation focus (i.e., imperiled species).
Where data structure and availability permit, national trends among species that make up these major species categories were supplemented with RPA regional trends. Each region is composed of multiple states that have been defined by the Forest Service for strategic resource planning purposes. These are the North, South, Rocky Mountain, and Pacific Coast Assessment regions. Base data were unable to be re-aggregated into the RPA regions for some species groups. In these instances, subnational trends for other geographic regions were reported when they were well established in wildlife monitoring and planning.
The nocturnal and secretive nature of many furbearers makes it difficult to evaluate the population status of most of these species. For this reason, harvest statistics were relied on as the only quantitative measure of status and trends for furbearers.
Because slope deviations from zero across many species of nongame was tested for, there is a legitimate concern that some significant trends could be observed solely due to chance. Although methodologies exist to reduce such errors, their implementation increases the chance that a species undergoing a true population increase or decline will be missed.

dataqual.logic: This information is unknown, as the data were obtained from other sources.
dataqual.complete:
A lack of data for a particular species in a state can occur because of variation in the geographical distribution (i.e., that particular species' geographic range does not include that state, and, therefore, nothing will be reported), the species is not regularly harvested in that state, or because of an actual reporting gap in the data (i.e., that particular species' geographic range includes the state, the species is regularly harvested, but for whatever reason no data were reported). All states with true data reporting gaps were identified over the 1975-2008 period. Data gaps in the time series were filled by linear interpolation when estimates were available for adjacent 5-year time periods (that is, time periods prior to and after the data gap). Although there is a limitation in this procedure because it assumes a linear trend in population or harvest across the gap year, the procedure allows more states to be considered in the overall analysis. Maximizing the number of states that contribute data helps ensure that the analysis of trends is not disproportionately influenced by data from one or a few states. When the data gap occurred at the terminal 2008 time period, 2007, 2009, or 2010 data were substituted when those were the only years for which the states could provide recent population or harvest estimates.
The data for Figures 30a and 30b are not included in this data publication. Contact the lead author of Radeloff et al. (2010) for data availability.

method.methdesc:
Big and Small Game: Data on big game populations and harvests were compiled primarily from cooperating state wildlife agencies. Supplemental long-term monitoring data from the North American Breeding Bird Survey was also used to evaluate national and regional wild turkey population trends (percentage change per year, posterior mean).
Data queries designed to facilitate data entry by state wildlife agencies were developed cooperatively over the years with input from the U.S. Forest Service and the Natural Resources Conservation Service. Data entry requests to state wildlife agencies were coordinated through the Association of Fish and Wildlife Agencies, with follow-up requests to states facilitated by Responsive Management. An electronic form for documenting population and harvest trends for selected species from 1975 through 2008 (in 5-year intervals except for the 3-year interval from 2005 to 2008) was provided to State Wildlife Directors along with data entry instructions. State biologists within each agency were asked to review historical estimates (acquired in previous RPA Assessment efforts) for accuracy, to provide estimates that were missing from the historical record, and to provide new estimates since the 2000 RPA Assessment (Flather, Brady, Knowles 1999) for 2005 and 2008 (some states provided estimates for 2007, 2009, or 2010 for the most recent estimate of population or harvest). Forms were returned electronically and entered into the RPA Wildlife database. All states responded to the request for information.
Trends were reported for a particular big game species only across those states that provided estimates (or for which data gaps could be filled) for the 1975 to 2008 period in 5-year intervals (with the exception of the last interval of 2005 to 2008). Previous RPA Assessments reported population and harvest trends for widespread (occurring in many states) species including black bear, deer (both white-tailed and mule deer combined), elk, pronghorn, and wild turkey. For this assessment we were able to generate separate population and harvest trends for white-tailed deer and mule deer. Even after implementing the above procedures to maximize the number of states contributing to national and regional trends, there were cases where some species had few states reporting data over the full 33 year period. Those trends that are based on only a few states should be interpreted with caution.
Migratory Game Birds: Survey methodologies have changed for migratory birds since the 2000 RPA Assessment when estimates were based on questionnaires sent to hunters who purchased a federal duck stamp. Hunters who sought only webless migratory species were not required to purchase a duck stamp and, therefore, were not sampled, resulting in an underestimate for those species. The Harvest Information Program (HIP) was developed to address this issue and was designed to sample all hunters of migratory birds.
Furbearers: Fur harvest data from 1970 to 2008 were compiled by the U.S. Furbearer Conservation Technical Work Group of the Association of Fish and Wildlife Agencies with assistance from state wildlife agencies (Association of Fish and Wildlife Agencies 2010). Sources varied between agencies and years and included fur buyers, fur dealers, fur trapper reports, pelt tagging records, and questionnaires. Depending on each state's methodology, the totals may or may not include hunter harvest. For most species, the totals presented are largely trapper harvest and should be considered a minimum harvest.
Nongame: The North American Breeding Bird Survey (BBS) was used to evaluate the status and trends among commonly occurring species throughout the United States. The BBS is an annual survey of more than 4,000 rural roadside routes, each 24.5 miles long, randomly located throughout the United States and Canada. Trained surveyors tally all birds seen or heard during a 3-minute period at 50 stops evenly spaced (half mile interval) along the route. Trends were estimated route-by-route and then averaged among routes occurring in regions of interest. Differences in regional sampling coverage and survey quality are accounted for by weighting route data when estimating the average regional trend. Trends were estimated over two broad periods of time: long-term trends were estimated over the 1966-2008 period and short-term trends were estimated over the 1996-2008 period to assess the degree to which bird trends have changed from the previous RPA Assessment.
To qualify for analysis, each bird species had to have been detected on at least 15 routes. Species were counted as having an increasing or decreasing trend if the slope of the regression differed from zero with probability P<0.05 in a positive or negative direction, respectively. Regression slopes that were not significantly different from zero were counted as stable.
Relative abundance trends for each species were summarized in two ways. First, the number of species with statistically significant increasing, decreasing, or stable trends nationwide were estimated and for each RPA region. Second, to provide a more detailed accounting of how birds with different ecologies have responded to changes in the environment, birds were grouped according to life-history characteristics, including nest type/location (cavity, open cup, ground or low, midstory or canopy), migration status (neotropical migrant, short-distance migrant, permanent resident), and breeding habitat affinity (woodland, shrubland, grassland, wetland or open water, urban) according to the classification of Peterjohn and Sauer (1993), and then each life-history group was analyzed. Specifically, the number of species with increasing, decreasing, or stable trends was estimated separately for each life-history group. To compare the pattern of breeding bird trends among life history groups and among RPA regions, weighted means of the percentage of birds with increasing or decreasing trends were estimated by using the number of species within each group that occurred in a particular RPA region as the weights.
Occurrence patterns of at-risk amphibians was supplemented with actual species occupancy trend estimates based on the Amphibian Research and Monitoring Initiative (ARMI). Initial occupancy trend analysis was reviewed from 118 time series ranging from 2 to 9 years over the 2002-2011 period for 50 species of amphibians.
For more details on the methods, see Flather, Knowles, Jones, and Schilli (2013).

citeinfo.title: North American Breeding Bird Survey annual summary 1990-1991
Big and Small Game Population and Harvest Estimates
citeinfo.othercit: Data acquired with the assistance of the Association of Fish and Wildlife Agencies and Responive Mangement.

srcinfo.srccontr: Data acquired with the assistance of the Association of Fish and Wildlife Agencies and Responsive Management. Requests were sent to all 50 state wildlife agencies to review the accuracy of population and harvest estimates for recreationally important big and small game species. Data were provided to the state agencies with estimates from 1975 to 2000, in 5-year intervals, with requests to confirm historical entries and provide recent estimates of harvest and population levels for 2005 and 2008.
Data for three time periods provided: 1966-1996 1997-2008 1966-2008

Total duck population estimates for the traditional survey area, 1955-2010. Includes mallards*, gadwall*, American wigeon*, green-winged teal*, blue-winged teal*, northern shoveler*, northern pintail*, redhead*, canvasback*, scaup*, American black duck, ring-necked duck, goldeneyes, bufflehead, and ruddy duck. Excludes scoters, eiders, long-tailed ducks, mergansers and wood ducks. The current (2010) population estimates for the 10 principal duck species, indicated with a asterisk (*) above, in the traditional survey area.

citeinfo.origin: U. S. Fish and Wildlife Service
citeinfo.title: 1994 Update to the North American Waterfolw Management Plan - Expanding the Commitment.

srcinfo.srccitea: Migratory Game Birds -- Duck population goals
srcinfo.srccontr: Continental population goals for ducks were obtained from the 1994 update to the North American Waterfowl Management Plan and do not change from year to year (Source: Kathy Fleming, pers. comm. U.S. Department of the Interior, U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Division of Migratory Bird Management, Branch of Population and Habitat Assessment, Laurel, MD. 10 Jan 2011).

Despite a change in methodology in 1999 to the Harvest Information Program (HIP), at the flyway and U.S. levels, duck harvest estimates are consistent enough to combine with data used from the 2000 RPA Assessment.

pubinfo.publish: U.S. Department of the Interior, U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Office of Migratory Bird Management

srcinfo.srccontr:
North American Canada goose population estimates for the 1970-2010 period. The survey for the Atlantic Flyway Resident Population did not change but the way the total population index was calculated changed. The difference is in how the treatment of the birds observed as singles, and as pairs, were treated.
The population indices for the Mississippi Flyway Giant Population/Resident Population (MFGP/MFRP) since 1992/93 were those obtained during spring in the Mississippi Flyway States/Provinces. Those used in the previous Assessment (1969-1995) were winter estimates obtained during mid-December or early January. The two methods are not comparable (Source: Tim Moser, pers. comm. Division of Migratory Bird Management. U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Laurel, MD. 20 Jan 2011).

pubinfo.publish: U.S. Department of the Interior, U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Office of Migratory Bird Management

srcinfo.srccontr: Despite a change in methodology in 1999 to the Harvest Information Program (HIP), at the flyway and U.S. levels, geese harvest estimates are consistent enough to combine with data used for the previous Assessment.

The different time series for the Western (1970-2010) and Eastern (1982-2010) swan populations is based on revisions to the 2007 Management Plan for the Eastern swan population (EP). Prior to the revision, the index for the EP was based on the Atlantic Flyway mid-winter survey (MWS). The 2007 Management Plan changed the index to include the Mississippi Flyway and Ontario MWS, with Ontario not tallying swans until 1982 (Sources: Mark Koneff, pers. comm. U.S. Department of the Interior, U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Division of Migratory Bird Management, Laurel, MD. 4 Aug 2009. Tim Moser, pers. comm. U.S. Department of the Interior, U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Division of Migratory Bird Management, Laurel, MD. 10 Aug 2011).

pubinfo.publish: U.S. Department of the Interior, U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Division of Migratory Bird Management, Branch of Harvest Surveys
U.S. Department of the Interior, Fish and Wildlife Service, Division of Migratory Bird Management

srcinfo.srccitea: Migratory Game Birds -- Mourning Dove population
srcinfo.srccontr: Since doves are managed by Management Unit, they generally don't report population estimates at larger scales, i.e., national. Band data appropriate for analysis for 2003-2009 was provided (Source: Sanders, Todd. Pers. comm., U.S. Department of the Interior, U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Division of Migratory Bird Management, Laurel, MD. 4 Jan 2011).

citeinfo.title: Migratory bird hunting activity and harvest during the 1999 and 2000 hunting seasons – Final Report

srcinfo.srccitea: Migratory Game Birds -- Mourning Dove harvest, 1999/2000
srcinfo.srccontr:
Harvest data differ from the previous Assessment because of the implementation of the Harvest Information Program (HIP) in 1999. HIP was cooperatively developed by the Fish and Wildlife Service (FWS) and state wildlife agencies to provide reliable annual estimates of hunter activity and harvest for all migratory game birds (Elden et al. 2002). In the past, the annual FWS migratory bird harvest survey (Mail Questionnaire Survey) was based on a sampling frame that consisted solely of hunters who purchased a federal duck stamp. However, people that hunt only non-waterfowl species such as doves were not required to purchase a duck stamp, and therefore were not included in that sampling frame. The HIP sampling frame consists of all migratory game bird hunters, thus providing more reliable estimates of dove hunter numbers and harvest than in the past. HIP survey estimates of dove harvest have been available since 1999. Although estimates from 1999-2002 have been finalized, the estimates from 2003-08 should be considered preliminary as refinements are still being made in the sampling frame and estimation techniques.
Elden R.C., W.V. Bevill, P.I. Padding, J.E. Frampton, and D.L. Shroufe. 2002. Pages 7-16 in J.M. Ver Steeg and R.C. Elden, compilers. Harvest Information Program: Evaluation and Recommendations. International Association of Fish and Wildlife Agencies, Migratory Shore and Upland Game Bird Working Group, Ad Hoc Committee on HIP, Washington, D.C.

Harvest data differ from the previous Assessment because of the implementation of the Harvest Information Program (HIP) in 1999. HIP was cooperatively developed by the Fish and Wildlife Service (FWS) and state wildlife agencies to provide reliable annual estimates of hunter activity and harvest for all migratory game birds (Elden et al. 2002). In the past, the annual FWS migratory bird harvest survey (Mail Questionnaire Survey) was based on a sampling frame that consisted solely of hunters who purchased a federal duck stamp. However, people that hunt only non-waterfowl species such as woodcock were not required to purchase a duck stamp, and therefore were not included in that sampling frame. The HIP sampling frame consists of all migratory game bird hunters, thus providing more reliable estimates of woodcock hunter numbers and harvest than in the past. HIP survey estimates of woodcock harvest have been available for woodcock since 1999. Although estimates from 1999-2002 have been finalized, the estimates from 2003-08 should be considered preliminary as refinements are still being made in the sampling frame and estimation techniques.

Although estimates from 1999-2002 have been finalized, the estimates from 2003-08 should be considered preliminary as refinements are still being made in the sampling frame and estimation techniques.

Harvest data differ from the previous Assessment because of the implementation of the Harvest Information Program (HIP) in 1999. HIP was cooperatively developed by the Fish and Wildlife Service (FWS) and state wildlife agencies to provide reliable annual estimates of hunter activity and harvest for all migratory game birds (Elden et al. 2002). In the past, the annual FWS migratory bird harvest survey (Mail Questionnaire Survey) was based on a sampling frame that consisted solely of hunters who purchased a federal duck stamp. However, people that hunt only non-waterfowl species such as woodcock were not required to purchase a duck stamp, and therefore were not included in that sampling frame. The HIP sampling frame consists of all migratory game bird hunters, thus providing more reliable estimates of woodcock hunter numbers and harvest than in the past. HIP survey estimates of woodcock harvest have been available for woodcock since 1999. Although estimates from 1999-2002 have been finalized, the estimates from 2003-08 should be considered preliminary as refinements are still being made in the sampling frame and estimation techniques.

Harvest data differ from the previous Assessment because of the implementation of the Harvest Information Program (HIP) in 1999. HIP was cooperatively developed by the Fish and Wildlife Service (FWS) and state wildlife agencies to provide reliable annual estimates of hunter activity and harvest for all migratory game birds (Elden et al. 2002). In the past, the annual FWS migratory bird harvest survey (Mail Questionnaire Survey) was based on a sampling frame that consisted solely of hunters who purchased a federal duck stamp. However, people that hunt only non-waterfowl species such as woodcock were not required to purchase a duck stamp, and therefore were not included in that sampling frame. The HIP sampling frame consists of all migratory game bird hunters, thus providing more reliable estimates of woodcock hunter numbers and harvest than in the past. HIP survey estimates of woodcock harvest have been available for woodcock since 1999. Although estimates from 1999-2002 have been finalized, the estimates from 2003-08 should be considered preliminary as refinements are still being made in the sampling frame and estimation techniques.

The HIP sampling frame consists of all migratory game bird hunters, thus providing more reliable estimates of woodcock hunter numbers and harvest than in the past. HIP survey estimates of woodcock harvest have been available for woodcock since 1999. Although estimates from 1999-2002 have been finalized, the estimates from 2003-08 should be considered preliminary as refinements are still being made in the sampling frame and estimation techniques.

HIP was cooperatively developed by the Fish and Wildlife Service (FWS) and state wildlife agencies to provide reliable annual estimates of hunter activity and harvest for all migratory game birds (Elden et al. 2002). Although estimates from 1999-2002 have been finalized, the estimates from 2003-08 should be considered preliminary as refinements are still being made in the sampling frame and estimation techniques.

pubinfo.publish: Association of Fish and Wildlife Agencies

srcinfo.srccontr: Fur harvest have been compiled by the U.S. Furbearer Conservation Technical Work Group (USFCTWG) of the Association of Fish and Wildlife Agencies (AFWA) in conjunction with the assistance of state wildlife agencies. Fur harvest data sources varied between agencies and years. Sources of information included fur buyer, fur dealer and fur trapper reports. In some states, pelt tagging records and periodic trapper questionnaires were also utilized. Depending on the methodology used, the total figures for a particular species may or may not include hunter harvest. For most species, the harvest data presented are largely trapper harvest and should be considered a minimum harvest.

citeinfo.title: North American Breeding Bird Survey ftp data set, version 2009.1

srcinfo.srccontr: Population trends were based on the North American Breeding Bird Survey (BBS) data. The BBS is a cooperative effort between the U.S. Geological Survey's Patuxent Wildlife Research Center and Environment Canada's Canadian Wildlife Service to monitor the status and trends of North American bird populations. Over 4100 survey routes are located across the continental U.S. and Canada. Survey routes are 24.5 miles long with stops at 0.5-mile intervals. At each stop, a 3-minute point count is conducted. During the count, every bird seen within a 0.25-mile radius or heard is recorded. Surveys start one-half hour before local sunrise and take about 5 hours to complete. We focused only on U.S. routes. (Source: John Sauer, pers. comm., U.S. Geological Survey, Biological Resources Division, Patuxent Wildlife Research Center. 2010)

citeinfo.title: North American Breeding Bird Survey ftp data set, version 2009.1

srcinfo.srccontr: Forest bird species richness was calculated by (1) extracting forest-associated species from the Breeding Bird Survey (BBS) data for each BBS route, (2) run the route-level data through COMDYN (https://www.mbr-pwrc.usgs.gov/software/) which computes estimates of species richness using large scale data, and (3) using ESRI's ArcMap software, map the COMDYN species richness estimates using the inverse distance weighting (IDW) interpolation method.

citeinfo.title: Status and trends of amphibian declines and extinctions world-wide

srcinfo.srccontr: Review of amphibian population assessment.

citeinfo.title: White-nose syndrome and bat hibernation areas

srcinfo.srccontr: The map documents counties with confirmed or suspected cases of white-nose syndrome from 2006/2007 to 2010/2011. Figure was re-created from the figure on the URL.

citeinfo.title: Status of pollinators in North America

srcinfo.srccontr: Review of pollinator population status from various literature sources.

citeinfo.title: Global pollinator declines: trends, impacts and drivers

srcinfo.srccontr: Review of pollinator population status from various literature sources.

citeinfo.title: North American Breeding Bird Survey ftp data set, version 2009.1

srcinfo.srccontr: Population trends of bird pollinators (hummingbirds) were based on the North American Breeding Bird Survey (BBS) data. We focused only on U.S. routes.

NatureServe's Central databases (NatureServe 2011) were queried for the count of species according to NatureServe's global conservation status ranks (http://www.natureserve.org/explorer/ranking.htm). At-risk species included those determined to be critically imperiled (G1), imperiled (G2), or vulnerable (G3) to extinction. Species of conservation concern include at-risk species and those species that are presumed to be extinct (GX) or are considered to be possibly extinct (GH). We report the percentage of total species that are considered to be at-risk or of conservation concern.

Trends in the number of species by broad taxonomic groups were compiled from the U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service’s Endangered Species Bulletin and on-line resources that keep the current count of U.S. threatened and endangered species, subspecies, and distinct population segments.

NatureServe's Central databases (NatureServe 2010) were queried for counts of species within counties that are formally listed as threatened or endangered under the ESA or are considered to be at-risk of extinction. Maps of ESA-listed species or at-risk species within counties were summarized into approximate percentile classes to highlight those counties with relatively high species counts.

NatureServe's Central databases (NatureServe 2011) were queried for the count of species according to NatureServe's global conservation status ranks (//www.natureserve.org/explorer/ranking.htm). At-risk species included those determined to be critically imperiled (G1), imperiled (G2), or vulnerable (G3) to extinction. Species of conservation concern include at-risk species and those species that are presumed to be extinct (GX) or are considered to be possibly extinct (GH). We report the percentage of total species that are considered to be at-risk or of conservation concern.

srcinfo.srccitea: Appendix C -- Threatened and endangered species
srcinfo.srccontr: NatureServe's Central databases (NatureServe 2010) were queried for the count of species according to NatureServe's global conservation status ranks (//www.natureserve.org/explorer/ranking.htm).

procstep.procdesc: (Process steps are a part of the methods section listed above)

overview.eaover: This data publication contains both the figures and data, for Flather et al. (2013). Data are available as either ArcGIS shapefiles or comma-delimited ASCII text files. Included in the full data publication download is the UsersGuide_EntityAttributes.pdf document: which contains a list of all the figures and data files available. It also includes a complete description of every variable in the tabular data files. The ArcGIS data files each have an associated metadata document (*.shp.xml) that contain additional information.
overview.eadetcit: Flather, Curtis H.; Knowles, Michael S.; Jones, Martin F.; Schilli, Carol. 2013. Wildlife population and harvest trends in the United States: A technical document supporting the Forest Service 2010 RPA Assessment. Gen. Tech. Rep. RMRS-GTR-296. Fort Collins, CO: U.S. Department of Agriculture, Forest Service, Rocky Mountain Research Station. 94 p. https://doi.org/10.2737/RMRS-GTR-296

cntorgp.cntorg: USDA Forest Service, Research and Development

cntinfo.cntinst: This contact information was current as of February 2023. For current information see Contact Us page on: https://doi.org/10.2737/RDS.

distinfo.distliab:
Metadata documents have been reviewed for accuracy and completeness. Unless otherwise stated, all data and related materials are considered to satisfy the quality standards relative to the purpose for which the data were collected. However, neither the author, the Archive, nor any part of the federal government can assure the reliability or suitability of these data for a particular purpose. The act of distribution shall not constitute any such warranty, and no responsibility is assumed for a user's application of these data or related materials.
The metadata, data, or related materials may be updated without notification. If a user believes errors are present in the metadata, data or related materials, please use the information in (1) Identification Information: Point of Contact, (2) Metadata Reference: Metadata Contact, or (3) Distribution Information: Distributor to notify the author or the Archive of the issues.
